awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Microfabrication and Self-Assembly of Shape-Changing Hydrogels with Chromonic Liquid Crystalline Order
awd_abstract_narration:
Shape-changing liquid crystal hydrogels are soft, rubbery materials that can perform mechanical work as "artificial" muscles, without motors, joints, or control systems. They move spontaneously in response to slight temperature changes, and can be designed to flex in different geometries. This collaborative research effort focuses on developing techniques to engineer these materials to produce novel devices such as self-cleaning surfaces. Like the cilia that sweep contaminants from human lungs, surfaces will be coated with micro-scale hydrogel structures that move as temperature fluctuates. These novel active coatings will address a critical need for self-cleaning devices in healthcare applications, and could prevent bacterial contamination that leads to frequent infections and thousands of deaths annually in the United States. In addition, community outreach efforts will be designed that engage young students and will help to broaden the diversity of the technical workforce, and research internships will help prepare high school students for advanced studies in science and engineering. 

Smart, programmable materials that respond mechanically to environmental stimuli are needed for smart biomedical devices. Hydrogels with chromonic liquid crystalline order are of interest for such applications because they morph anisotropically in response to biologically-benign temperature changes, and because their actuation trajectory can be programmed by patterning the material's molecular alignment. A key challenge is to fabricate such complex actuators at length scales too small to access via 3D printing and in shape profiles that are not flat films. This award supports development of novel techniques for design and microfabrication of shape-morphing hydrogels, using hierarchical patterning of molecular orientation achieved by combining soft lithography and liquid crystal self-assembly. This fundamental research will test the hypothesis that the shape of soft lithography molds can be used to pattern molecular alignment in micro-scale structures made of chromonic liquid crystal hydrogels, and that these aligned hydrogels can undergo programmable actuation in response to biologically-benign temperature changes. This processing approach will be used to create artificial cilia-like structures. Experimental efforts will be closely coupled to theory/simulation at two levels. First, the molecular order (nematic director) arising from surface anchoring from the soft lithography mold and liquid crystal chirality will be modeled. Second, nonlinear finite element elastodynamics simulations will be used to model shape evolution of active hydrogel micro-devices with a given director field as they transform under stimulus. This collaborative project brings together a multidisciplinary team with complementary expertise in responsive materials chemistry, materials modeling, and mechanical design.

por.por_cntn:
Liquid crystal phases are observed in materials composed of non-spherical molecules, for example with molecules shaped like rods or disks. Beyond the usual states of matter--crystal, liquid, and gas -- liquid crystals represent a family of phases that are less ordered than a regular solid crystal, but more ordered than an isotropic liquid. Each phase is stable over a specific range of temperature. Rod-shaped molecules often form a ''nematic'' phase where molecules spontaneously align parallel to each other. This name is inspired by the Greek word “nema” that means ''thread,'' for the thread-like defect lines, called disclinations, that form in the nematic phase.

Rod-shaped molecules can also form a nematic phase when incorporated into a polymer network interconnected by chemical bonds to form a stretchy, elastic solid. When heated, these materials undergo a dramatic change of shape by contracting along the direction of molecular alignment, like an artificial muscle, then relax back to their original shape when cooled. A nematic polymer network made with a pattern of different molecular alignment directions can flex in more complicated ways such as twisting or folding when heated.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in development of theoretical methods to model and design temperature-responsive shape change in nematic polymer networks. We focused on modeling thin layers of nematic polymers as a coating on glass, and showed that by patterning the material with an array of disclination lines, we can program different types of shape transformations. We showed how to make an initially flat coating layer transform to a new shape whose surface has indented channels, bumps, dimples, or suction cups resembling octopus suckers. Our simulation models were validated by comparing with experiments by collaborators. The temperature-responsive coatings we studied have engineering applications due to their switchable properties including optical reflection, wettability, and friction. They can also be used as a surface layer to culture biological cells.

We also explored ways to organize disclination lines in nematic liquid crystals by confining the material between two glass slides, each patterned with a surface ''anchoring'' layer that locally controls molecular orientation. By using different surface anchoring patterns, we designed and modeled many different defect textures. These include an array of straight disclination lines lying either parallel or perpendicular to the glass slides; curved disclinations that connect to special points on one or both anchoring layers; or an array of closed disclination loops that lie in a plane between the two substrates. Our theoretical studies were closely coordinated with experiments by collaborators. These textures represent a form of ''materials by design'' and have applications in optical devices, and can also be used to control assembly of colloid particles.

Our work on modeling defect lines also revealed a surprising connection between the behavior of disclinations in nematic liquid crystals and the behavior of defect lines in metals. When you bend a metal paper clip, defect lines called dislocations are generated via the so-called Frank-Read mechanism, where a defect line pinned at two spots along its length repeatedly bows out and snaps off new loops. Generation and motion of dislocations enable the crystalline metal to deform. We demonstrated that the same Frank-Read mechanism generates disclination loops in a nematic liquid crystal when it is twisted between two glass substrates. The mechanism was confirmed in an experiment by collaborators. While defect pinning occurs through random processes in metals, in a nematic liquid crystal cell we can inscribe pinning points on the substrates by patterning the anchoring layers, providing a novel method to control defect generation.

Broader impacts of this project include activities for students in Northeast Ohio to engage in hands-on science research. We held three annual science fair events for students in grades 4-12, co-organized with the Northeast Ohio STEM Alliance and hosted at Kent State University. We also organized an individual investigation course at Kent State that provides a hands-on STEM research internship experience for dual-enrolled students from area high schools. This part-time internship opportunity was offered during fall, spring, and summer semesters, with supervision by Kent State faculty.
